"SECTION 1. FINDINGS."

Summarized: Section 1 presents the findings. "Congress finds that Jackie Robinson, born in 1919 in Georgia, excelled in multiple sports at UCLA and became the first black player in Major League Baseball in 1947, a significant moment in sports history." Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier in Major League Baseball in 1947 by signing with the Brooklyn Dodgers. He won the National League's Rookie of the Year Award in his first season and was later named the National League's Most Valuable Player in 1949. Robinson was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962. In 1949, Jackie Robinson was voted the National League's Most Valuable Player and in 1962, he was elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame. Robinson's achievements in athletics had a significant impact on civil and human rights in America. Jackie Robinson, the first black player in Major League Baseball, was signed before the desegregation of the US military, civil rights marches in the South, and the Brown v. Board of Education ruling. He quickly gained public admiration for his fortitude, integrity, and athletic ability, surpassing notable figures like President Harry Truman and General Dwight Eisenhower by the end of 1947. Jackie Robinson's popularity soared in 1947, surpassing President Harry Truman and General Dwight Eisenhower in a national poll. He later became vice president of Chock Full O' Nuts and co-founded the Freedom National Bank of Harlem, influencing many political leaders in America. Jackie Robinson became vice president of Chock Full O' Nuts in 1957 and co-founded the Freedom National Bank of Harlem. He influenced political leaders and worked with various organizations to improve the lives of Americans. His legacy is honored through the Jackie Robinson Foundation, providing leadership and educational opportunities to children from low-income families. The Jackie Robinson Foundation preserves his legacy by providing leadership and educational opportunities to children from low-income families, contributing to the advancement of civil rights in the United States. The President is authorized to present a gold medal to Jackie Robinson's family in recognition of his contributions to the nation. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike the medal with suitable emblems. Duplicate medals are also authorized. The Secretary is authorized to strike and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal at a price covering costs. The medals are considered national medals. Authorization of appropriations is also granted. The medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. An amount not to exceed $30,000 is authorized to be charged to pay for the medal, with proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals deposited in the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. Additionally, there is a sense of Congress included in the Act. The Congress recognizes the accomplishments of Jackie Robinson and calls for a national day in his honor. The President is urged to issue a proclamation for observing the day with appropriate ceremonies and activities. The 108th Congress passed a bill to award a congressional gold medal to Jackie Robinson posthumously for his contributions to the nation and to establish a national day in his honor.
